transcripts.text: So I'm here outside of Fox News' New York headquarters where Media Matters and a bunch of other organizations are heading a protest on the same day that Fox is having a pre-planned meeting with media buyers to try to rebrand their network and get advertisers back to the network.  Fox News lies!  Fox News lies!  Fox News lies!  This week, a plethora of misogynistic, racist, xenophobic comments were unearthed of Tucker Carlson's where he called Iraqis monkeys, where he defended statutory rape.  The list goes on and on.  And people are protesting that advertisers are still buying time on his program.
The best thing that America can do is shut off fake news.
And that would start with Fox.  And that would start with all of their programming.

When I say Foxes, you say sexes.  We have no expectation of Fox to do anything.  We don't expect them to do the right thing.  But what we do expect is that advertisers will respond to the bottom line, which is money.  And what we're saying is that Fox is bad for business.  And in particular, women are actually huge economic drivers.  Women are the targets of a lot of advertisements, actually.  And frankly, if you want women to buy your products, you can't advertise on Fox News.  And that's the message we're sending.

This is part of what's often called the fourth estate.  The fourth estate is supposed to operate as a check.  When you have a news organization whose owner, Rupert Murdoch, is in regular conversations with Donald Trump, who are actively burying stories that would have been damaging to Trump's presidential campaign, you have a problem with the fourth estate.  And I think that is another issue that advertisers should be concerned about.

Fox News is a uniquely destructive force.  And I think, you know, if they had even the most basic standards like any other news outlet did, I think I'm fine with them having an ideological perspective, but they'd operate with total impunity with destructive consequences.

Last week, Jeanine Pirro on her program also said that Representative Ilhan Omar was more loyal to the Koran and to Sharia law because she wore a hijab as well.  That's what the protesters are here speaking out against as well.

Now, I'm a Jewish woman, okay?  And I'm going to tell you, they don't care.  They don't care at all.  What they like to do is they like to use us and weaponize us against leftist movements, against Muslims, and against people of color.  But we are not going to buy it.  Women aren't buying it.  Jews aren't buying it.

We're not buying it when they promote the exact same dangerous conspiracy theories about women and Jews that put us in real harm's way.  We're not buying it, and we are sure as hell not buying from the companies that profit off of it.  One of the ideas and the parts of the agenda is to promote the notion that the left is deeply anti-Semitic, which makes their cause feel righteous.  But underneath all of that is this notion that it is totally acceptable to engage in bigotry against Muslims or any other.  And that's the part where I think the tension really starts to come in because her attack on Muslims, suggesting that Omar, Representative Omar, is somehow violating the Constitution by wearing a hijab, I think reveals that it isn't just a matter of promoting one side.  There's always a second part of the coin when it comes to Fox News.  So while they're driving a wedge, they're also simultaneously advancing a pretty disturbing perspective.
